case_name: Writ Petition No. 154 of 1966 (Roshan Lal Tandon)

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 154 of 1966 filed by Roshan Lal Tandon under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: Ramaswami, J.-In this case the petitioner, Roshan La1 Tandon has obtained a rule from this Court calling upon the respondents to show cause why a writ in the nature of mandamus under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India should number be issued companymanding the respondents number to carry out the directives companytained in the numberification of the Railway Board No. E NG 65 PMI-26 dated the 27 the October, 1965, Annexure D to the Writ Petition, in so far as it grants protection to the existing Apprentice Train Examiners and lays down the procedure to fill upgraded vacancies.

facts.text: Railway Board issued notification No. E NG 65 PMI-26 dated October 27, 1965, changing recruitment rules for Train Examiners.

anchor.surface_text: On October 27, 1965 the Railway Board issued the impugned numberification  Annexure D to the Writ Petition . The numberification states in the first place that on and from April 1, 1966 vacancies in the Entry Grade of Train Examiners scale Rs. 120-240 should number be filled from Apprentice Train Examiners upto 50 as hitherto, but should exclusively be filled by promotion from amongst artisan staff With regard to the next higher grade i.e., Grade C, it was provided that 80 vacancies should be filled by Apprentice Train Examiners who had successfully companypleted the prescribed training of 5 years  three years in case of Diploma Holders and three years in case of Artisan recruited as Apprentice Train Examiner .

facts.text: Originally two scales for Train Examiners: Rs. 100-185 (D Grade) and Rs. 150-225 (C Grade), later revised to Rs. 180-240 and Rs. 205-280.

anchor.surface_text: Cause has been shown by, the respondents to whom numberice of the rule was ordered to be given. There were originally two scales for Train Examiners Rs. 100-185  D Grade  and Rs. 150-225  C Grade . These scales were later revised as a result of the recommendations of the Second Pay Commission and the scale of D Grade was increased to Rs. 180-240 and that of C Grade to Rs. 205-

facts.text: Railway Board letter No. PC-60/PS5/TP-8 dated February 18, 1961: 50% vacancies in Entry Grade Rs. 180-240 filled from Apprentice Train Examiners after 4 years apprenticeship, 50% by promotion from skilled artisans.

anchor.surface_text: On February 18, 1961 the Railway Board issued a letter No. PC-60/PS5/ TP-8, Annexure A to the Writ Petition to the General Managers of all Indian Railways companyveying its decision that vacancies in the Entry Grade of Train Examiners  in the scale Rs. 180- 240  with effect from February 18, 1961 should be filled as follows 50 of the vacancies should be filled from Apprentice Train Examiners who successfully have companypleted the prescribed  4 years  apprenticeship, the remaining 50 of the vacancies being filled by promotion of skilled artisans.

facts.text: 20% of annual requirements of Apprentice Train Examiners drawn from skilled artisans not more than 35 years old on 1st July of the year apprenticeship commences.

anchor.surface_text: 20 /1/O of the annual requirements of Apprentice Train Examiners should be drawn from skilled artisans who are number more than 35 years old on 1st July of the year in which the apprenticeship is likely to companymence.

facts.text: Promotion to Grade C of Train Examiners on basis of seniority-cum-suitability without distinction between direct entry or from skilled artisans.

anchor.surface_text: Promotion to Grade C of Train Examiners used to take place on the basis of seniority-cum-suitability without any distinction whether the employee entered Grade D of the Train Examiners directly or was selected out of the category of skilled artisans.

facts.text: Railway Board letter No. E S 1-57-TRS/41 dated January 25, 1958: Promotion to TXR grade Rs. 150-225 solely on seniority-cum-suitability, 20% reservation no longer operative.

anchor.surface_text: This rule was laid down by the Railway Board in its letter No. E S  1-57-TRS/41, dated January 25, 1958 which states Ref Para 2 of Boards letter No. E R  49- JAC 13 dated 23-2-50 laying down that 20 of the posts in the TXR grade Rs. 150-225 should be reserved and the TXR in the grade of Rs. 80-160  since revised Rs. 100-185  promoted from skilled and semi-skilled ranks. The Board have reviewed the position and have decided that promotion to the TXR grade of Rs. 150-225 should hereafter be made solely on the basis of seniority-cum-suitability and the reservation of only 20 as mentioned above will numberlonger be operative.

facts.text: Divisional Personnel Officer, New Delhi prepared seniority list for Train Examiners Grade D of Delhi Division as on December 31, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of this rule the Divisional Personnel Officer, New Delhi, prepared a seniority list for the Train Examiners of Grade D of Delhi Division as on December 31, 1964  Annexure C to the Writ Petition .

facts.text: October 27, 1965 notification: From April 1, 1966, entry grade vacancies Rs. 180-240 exclusively filled by promotion from artisan staff.

anchor.surface_text: On October 27, 1965 the Railway Board issued the impugned numberification  Annexure D to the Writ Petition . The numberification states in the first place that on and from April 1, 1966 vacancies in the Entry Grade of Train Examiners scale Rs. 120-240 should number be filled from Apprentice Train Examiners upto 50 as hitherto, but should exclusively be filled by promotion from amongst artisan staff.

facts.text: For Grade C Rs. 205-280: 80% vacancies filled by Apprentice Train Examiners after 5 years training (3 years for diploma holders or artisans), 20% from Grade D Train Examiners.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the next higher grade i.e., Grade C, it was provided that 80 vacancies should be filled by Apprentice Train Examiners who had successfully companypleted the prescribed training of 5 years  three years in case of Diploma Holders and three years in case of Artisan recruited as Apprentice Train Examiner . Twenty per cent of the vacancies were to be filled by the Train Examiners from Grade D.

facts.text: Existing Train Examiners Grade D who began as Apprentices absorbed in Grade C against 80% quota without selection; 20% by selection from other Grade D.

anchor.surface_text: It was further provided that the Train Examiners Grade D who began as Apprentice Train Examiners and who were to be absorbed in the C Grade against 80 vacancies reserved for them should number be required to undergo selection before being absorbed in that grade. As regards 20 vacancies reserved for the other class of Train Examiners the promotion was to be on selection basis.

facts.text: Roshan Lal Tandon entered railway service on March 6, 1954 as skilled fitter on Northern Railway.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, Roshan Lal Tandon entered railway service on March 6, 1954 as skilled fitter on the Northern Railway.

facts.text: Roshan Lal Tandon selected for training for Train Examiner Grade D on June 5, 1958, confirmed on October 25, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: He was selected for the training for the post of Train Examiner Grade D on June 5, 1958 and was companyfirmed in that grade on October 25, 1959.

facts.text: Petitioner claims that Apprentice Train Examiners and direct recruits from skilled artisans form one class in Grade D, promotion to C by seniority-cum-suitability irrespective of source.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the petitioner is that he alongwith the direct recruits formed one class in Entry grade D and their companydition of service was that seniority was to be reckoned from the date of appointment as Train Examiner in Grade D and promotion to Grade C was on the basis of seniority-cum-suitability test irrespective of the source of recruitment.

facts.text: Petitioner alleges impugned notification discriminates against non-apprentice Grade D Train Examiners for promotion to Grade C, violating Articles 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that there was numberdifference between the apprentices and those selected out of the skilled artisans when they entered Grade D and that portion of the impugned numberification which gave a favourable treatment to the direct recruits in Grade D with regard to promotion to Grade C was arbitrary and discriminatory and violated the guarantee under Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Respondent states prior to April 1, 1966 promotion to Grade C was seniority-cum-suitability, but changed to 80% direct from Apprentices, 20% from Grade D by merit for technical reasons.

anchor.surface_text: In the companynter-affidavit respondent No. 1 has denied that there was any violation of the guarantee under Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution. It was companyceded that prior to April 1, 1966 promotion to the post of Grade C Train Examiner was on the basis of seniority-cum-suitability but the impugned numberification was issued by the first respondent because it Was decided that the posts of senior Train Examiners in Grade C should be filled by men possessin adequate technical knowledge

facts.text: Reorganisation due to complicated designs, modern rolling stock, dieselisation, electrification requiring better trained personnel.

anchor.surface_text: The reason was that there were more companyplicated designs. of Carriages and Wagons, acquisition of modern type of Rolling Stock and greater speed of trains under dieselisation and electrification programmes. It was. companysidered that there should be a better calibre of technically trained and technically qualified personnel for proper maintenance and safety of the Rolling Stock.

facts.text: Court holds that direct recruits and promotees in Grade D form one class, cannot discriminate for promotion to Grade C.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the companystitutional objection taken by the petitioner to this part of the numberification is well-founded and must be accepted as companyrect. At the time when the petitioner and the direct recruits were appointed to Grade D, there was one class in Grade D formed of direct recruits and the promotees from the grade of artisans.

facts.text: Impugned notification discriminates by absorbing existing Apprentice TX in Grade D to C grade 80% without selection, while others by selection, violating Arts. 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: As a companysequence of the impugned numberification a discriminatory treatment is made in favour of the existing Apprentice Train Examiners who have already been absorbed in Grade D by March 31, 1966, because the numberification provides that this group of Apprentice Train Examiners should first be accommodated en bloc in grade C upto 80 per cent of vacancies reserved for them without undergoing any selec- tion. As regards the 20 per cent of the vacancies made available for the category of Train Examiners to which the petitioner belongs the basis of recruitment was selection on merit and the previous test of seniority-cum-suitability was abandoned.

facts.text: Court relies on Mervyn Coutinho case (1966 3 SCR 600) principle: single source of recruitment cannot have quota discrimination.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the present case falls within the principle of the recent decision of this Court in Mervyn Collector 1 . In that case, the petitioners who were Appraisers in the Customs Department filed a writ petition under Art. 32, challenging the validity of the rotational system as applied in fixing the seniority of Appraisers and Principal Appraisers.

facts.text: No contractual right in terms of service; government servant has status governed by rules unilaterally alterable.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the petitioner has numbervested companytractual right in regard to the terms of his service and that Counsel for the petitioner has been unable to make good his submission on this aspect of the case.

facts.text: Writ allowed quashing specific part of October 27, 1965 notification regarding absorption without selection and selection basis for others.

holdings.text: The constitutional objection taken by the petitioner to this part of the notification is well-founded and must be accepted as correct. At the time when the petitioner and the direct recruits were appointed to Grade D, there was one class in Grade D formed of direct recruits and the promotees from the grade of artisans. The recruits from both the sources to Grade D were integrated into one class and no discrimination could thereafter be made in favour of recruits from one source as against the recruits from the other source in the matter of promotion to Grade C.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the constitutional objection taken by the petitioner to this part of the notification is well-founded and must be accepted as correct. At the time when the petitioner and the direct recruits were appointed to Grade D, there was one class in Grade D formed of direct recruits and the promotees from the grade of artisans.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct recruits and promotees integrated into single class in Grade D; discrimination for promotion to Grade C based on source impermissible after integration.

holdings.text: As a consequence of the impugned notification a discriminatory treatment is made in favour of the existing Apprentice Train Examiners who have already been absorbed in Grade D by March 31, 1966, because the notification provides that this group of Apprentice Train Examiners should first be accommodated en bloc in grade C upto 80 per cent of vacancies reserved for them without undergoing any selection. As regards the 20 per cent of the vacancies made available for the category of Train Examiners to which the petitioner belongs the basis of recruitment was selection on merit and the previous test of seniority-cum-suitability was abandoned.

anchor.surface_text: As a consequence of the impugned notification a discriminatory treatment is made in favour of the existing Apprentice Train Examiners who have already been absorbed in Grade D by March 31, 1966, because the notification provides that this group of Apprentice Train Examiners should first be accommodated en bloc in grade C upto 80 per cent of vacancies reserved for them without undergoing any selec- tion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification creates unequal treatment: en bloc absorption without selection for one sub-group vs merit selection for others in same integrated cadre, violating equality.

In that case, the petitioners who were Appraisers in the Customs Department filed a writ petition under Art. 32, challenging the validity of the rotational system as applied in fixing the seniority of Appraisers and Principal Appraisers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to Mervyn Coutinho: single source of recruitment (Grade D) to higher grade (C) precludes quota or preferential treatment based on sub-categories or origin.

holdings.text: We are therefore of the opinion that the petitioner has no vested contractual right in regard to the terms of his service and that Counsel for the petitioner has been unable to make good his submission on this aspect of the case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Government service creates status governed by statutory rules unilaterally alterable by government; origin contractual but evolves to status under public law.

holdings.text: But for the reasons already expressed we hold that the impugned part of the notification violates the guarantee under Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution and a writ in the nature of mandamus should be issued commanding the first respondent not to give effect to the impugned part of the notification...
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative conclusion quashing specific discriminatory portion of notification and issuing mandamus based on Arts. 14/16 violation.

anchor.surface_text: Mervyn Collector 1 . In that case, the petitioners who were Appraisers in the Customs Department filed a writ petition under Art. 32, challenging the validity of the rotational system as applied in fixing the seniority of Appraisers and Principal A

precedents.cited_proposition: Once direct recruits and promotees are absorbed in one cadre they form one class and cannot be discriminated for the purpose of further promotion to the higher grade when there is only one source of recruitment for the higher grade
precedents.cited_holding: There is therefore no question of any quota being reserved from two sources in their cases. The rotational system cannot therefore apply when there is only one source of recruitment and no two sources of recruitment. In a case therefore where there is only one source of recruitment, the normal rule will apply...

anchor.surface_text: But for the reasons already expressed we hold that the impugned part of the notification violates the guarantee under Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution and a writ in the nature of mandamus should be issued commanding the first respondent not to give effect to the impugned part of the notification, viz., The Apprentice T.X.Rs. who have already been or will be absorbed in scale Rs. 180-240 upto 31-3-66 should first be accommodated in scale Rs. 205-280 against the quota of 80 vacancies reserved for them. Such staff should not be required to undergo a Selection before being absorbed in that grade. The upgraded vacancies in scale Rs. 205-280 left over after earmarking those for the apprentices under training on 2-4-66 should be filled by promotion of T.X.Rs. in scale Rs. 180-240 on a selection basis. While computing the number of posts available for promotion of T.X.Rs. in scale Rs. 180-240 the vacancies likely to occur during the period of apprenticeship of the apprentices under training as on 1-4-66 should also be taken into account. In other words, it would be necessary to keep in reserve only the number of posts equal to the number of apprentices under training as on 1-4-66, who cannot be absorbed in the anticipated vacancies which will arise by the time they qualify. The application is accordingly allowed, but there will be number,order with regard to companyts in this case.

outcome.relief_summary: Writ petition allowed; impugned part of Railway Board notification dated October 27, 1965 held violative of Articles 14 and 16; writ of mandamus issued commanding respondent not to implement the discriminatory provisions favouring existing Apprentice Train Examiners for absorption into Grade C without selection.
directions: Issue writ in the nature of mandamus commanding the first respondent not to give effect to the impugned part of the notification providing for absorption of existing Apprentice TXRs into Grade C (80% quota) without selection and filling remaining upgraded vacancies by selection from other TXRs in Grade D.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the constitutional objection taken by the petitioner to this part of the notification is well-founded and must be accepted as correct. At the time when the petitioner and the direct recruits were appointed to Grade D, there was one class in Grade D formed of direct recruits and the promotees from the grade of artisans.

But for the reasons already expressed we hold that the impugned part of the notification violates the guarantee under Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution and a writ in the nature of mandamus should be issued commanding the first respondent not to give effect to the impugned part of the notification, viz., The Apprentice T.X.Rs. who have already been or will be absorbed in scale Rs. 180-240 upto 31-3-66 should first be accommodated in scale Rs. 205-280 against the quota of 80 vacancies reserved for them. Such staff should not be required to undergo a Selection before being absorbed in that grade. The upgraded vacancies in scale Rs. 205-280 left over after earmarking those for the apprentices under training on 2-4-66 should be filled by promotion of T.X.Rs. in scale Rs. 180-240 on a selection basis. While computing the number of posts available for promotion of T.X.Rs. in scale Rs. 180-240 the vacancies likely to occur during the period of apprenticeship of the apprentices under training as on 1-4-66 should also be taken into account. In other words, it would be necessary to keep in reserve only the number of posts equal to the number of apprentices under training as on 1-4-66, who cannot be absorbed in the anticipated vacancies which will arise by the time they qualify. The application is accordingly allowed, but there will be number,order with regard to companyts in this case.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 on discriminatory treatment in favor of apprentices grounds c5's Art. 14 violation holding.
h2's discrimination finding supports h5's violation holding.

anchor.surface_text: As a consequence of the impugned notification a discriminatory treatment is made in favour of the existing Apprentice Train Examiners who have already been absorbed in Grade D by March 31, 1966, because the notification provides that this group of Apprentice Train Examiners should first be accommodated en bloc in grade C upto 80 per cent of vacancies reserved for them without undergoing any selec- tion.

But for the reasons already expressed we hold that the impugned part of the notification violates the guarantee under Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution and a writ in the nature of mandamus should be issued commanding the first respondent not to give effect to the impugned part of the notification, viz., The Apprentice T.X.Rs. who have already been or will be absorbed in scale Rs. 180-240 upto 31-3-66 should first be accommodated in scale Rs. 205-280 against the quota of 80 vacancies reserved for them. Such staff should not be required to undergo a Selection before being absorbed in that grade. The upgraded vacancies in scale Rs. 205-280 left over after earmarking those for the apprentices under training on 2-4-66 should be filled by promotion of T.X.Rs. in scale Rs. 180-240 on a selection basis. While computing the number of posts available for promotion of T.X.Rs. in scale Rs. 180-240 the vacancies likely to occur during the period of apprenticeship of the apprentices under training as on 1-4-66 should also be taken into account. In other words, it would be necessary to keep in reserve only the number of posts equal to the number of apprentices under training as on 1-4-66, who cannot be absorbed in the anticipated vacancies which will arise by the time they qualify. The application is accordingly allowed, but there will be number,order with regard to companyts in this case.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the present case falls within the principle of the recent decision of this Court in Mervyn Coutinho. In that case, the petitioners who were Appraisers in the Customs Department filed a writ petition under Art. 32, challenging the validity of the rotational system as applied in fixing the seniority of Appraisers and Principal Appraisers.

But for the reasons already expressed we hold that the impugned part of the notification violates the guarantee under Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution and a writ in the nature of mandamus should be issued commanding the first respondent not to give effect to the impugned part of the notification, viz., The Apprentice T.X.Rs. who have already been or will be absorbed in scale Rs. 180-240 upto 31-3-66 should first be accommodated in scale Rs. 205-280 against the quota of 80 vacancies reserved for them. Such staff should not be required to undergo a Selection before being absorbed in that grade. The upgraded vacancies in scale Rs. 205-280 left over after earmarking those for the apprentices under training on 2-4-66 should be filled by promotion of T.X.Rs. in scale Rs. 180-240 on a selection basis. While computing the number of posts available for promotion of T.X.Rs. in scale Rs. 180-240 the vacancies likely to occur during the period of apprenticeship of the apprentices under training as on 1-4-66 should also be taken into account. In other words, it would be necessary to keep in reserve only the number of posts equal to the number of apprentices under training as on 1-4-66, who cannot be absorbed in the anticipated vacancies which will arise by the time they qualify. The application is accordingly allowed, but there will be number,order with regard to companyts in this case.
